clinical_study.brief_title: Enhancing Operability in a Hypobaric Hypoxic Environment With a Small Oxygen Storage System
clinical_study.official_title: Enhancing Operability in a Hypobaric Hypoxic Environment With a Small Oxygen Storage System

brief_summary.textblock: This is a study to validate the efficacy of using a small portable oxygen source to mitigate altitude-induced hypoxia.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to validate the efficacy of using a small portable oxygen source to mitigate altitude-induced hypoxic events. To do so, the invesitgators propose the following aims:
1. Determine the ability of a portable oxygen storage device to reverse hypobaric hypoxemia in volunteers at altitude.
2. Determine the duration of time that a single portable oxygen container can maintain normoxia in normal volunteers at altitude.
3. Determine the optimum dose and timing of oxygen use to reverse hypobaric hypoxemia.

primary_outcome.measure: Elapsed time during which oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry (SpO2) remains above 90% I
primary_outcome.description: Elapsed time during which subject's SpO2 remains above 90% after initially reaching or exceeding 94% following exposure to a simulated altitude of 14,000 and after receiving pulse-dosed oxygen

secondary_outcome.measure: Amount of oxygen needed to return SpO2 to sea level value I
secondary_outcome.description: Amount of oxygen needed to return subject's SpO2 value to 94% (or higher) after exposure to a simulated altitude of 14,000 feet

secondary_outcome.measure: Amount of oxygen needed to return SpO2 to sea level value II
secondary_outcome.description: Amount of oxygen needed to return subject's SpO2 value to 94% (or higher) after (i) reaching SpO2 value of 82-84% or (ii) attaining 85% of maximum predicted heart rate. This is following exercise on a stationary bicycle at a simulated altitude of 10,000 feet

secondary_outcome.measure: Elapsed time during which SpO2 remains above 90% II
secondary_outcome.description: Elapsed time during which subject's SpO2 remains above 90% after initially following exposure to a simulated altitude of 14,000 and after initially (i) reaching SpO2 value of 82-84% or (ii) attaining 85% of maximum predicted heart rate. This is following exercise on a stationary bicycle at a simulated altitude of 10,000 feet and after receiving pulse-dosed oxygen.

study_pop.textblock: Normal volunteers aged 18 to 65 years, inclusive
